passages.text: Earnings Review: 1H25 headline results above but EBIT missed; challenging setup for margins vs. expectations; maintain Sell

Sinotruk reported its 1H25 results on Aug 27 after market close, and held an analyst briefing call on Aug 28. 1H25 NP of Rmb3.43bn (+4% yoy) was \(+5\%\) above GSe (see our preview note here) mainly on non- ops (e.g. FX gains). EBIT (+5% yoy) came in 3% below our previewed estimate, mainly due to weaker- than- expected top- line growth (only up \(+4\%\) yoy), with HDT volume growth partially offset by ASP decline across both domestic and overseas. The company declared interim cash dividend of Rmb1.88bn or HK\$0.74/share (55% payout ratio - unchanged yoy, implying 3% yield).

The results reaffirmed our relatively cautious views (vs. the Street) about Sinotruk's ambitious target on the margin expansion trajectory (+50bps p.a. over 2025E- 26E) as the company failed to improve its HDT OPM (flatish yoy) despite the domestic market recovery and the company's increased engine in- sourcing. We continue to believe the market has overestimated Sinotruk's operating leverage from the domestic HDT cycle recovery (due to the rising electrification) while underestimated the impact of the steeper- than- expected decline in exports into the CIS region, which has an outsized impact to Sinotruk's earnings (relative to its volume contribution given high pricing and unit profitability).

We raise our 2025E- 27E EPS estimates by 2- 7% to reflect the higher- than- expected non- ops and the positive impact of increased engine in- sourcing to margins but our revised estimates remain 9- 17% below Visible Alpha Consensus. Maintain Sell with a new 12- m TP of HK\$20 (vs. HK\$19.0 previously).
Market cap: HK\$60.7bn / \$7.8bn Enterprise value: HK\$41.5bn / \$5.3bn 3m ADTV: HK\$78.9mn / \$10.1mn
China Advanced Materials & Construction M&A Rank: 3 Leases incl. in net debt & EV?: Yes
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Research estimates. See disclosures for details.

SellSinotruk (3808.HK)Rating since Dec 16, 2024

Source: FactSet. Price as of 28 Aug 2025 close.
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Research estimates.
1H25 topline of Rmb50.88bn (+4% yoy) came in - 4% below our expectation, due to softer-than- expected overseas HDT sales (JV exports sales were down - 4% yoy in 1H25).

ASP was the key drag (down MSD% yoy in 1H25) as export volume stayed positive yoy (albeit mild at \(+1\%\) , vs. industry growth of \(+3\%\) ). We believe the ASP decline was due to geographic mix shifts to non- CIS regions where the ASP is lower relative to that in CIS region. Domestic HDT sales was solid at \(10\% +\) yoy growth, with solid volume \((+19\%)\) yoy) partially offset by weak ASP (also down MSD% yoy). As a result, HDT sales only grew \(+4\%\) yoy in 1H25.

For other products, LDT sales were up \(+6\%\) yoy, with \(+10\%\) yoy growth in volume partially offset by \(- 3\%\) yoy declined ASP, and company highlighted doubled yoy overseas sales (though revenue contribution remained low at \(5\%\) ). Engine sales saw robust growth of \(+26\%\) yoy (though revenue contribution was also low at \(1\%\) ).
1H25 GPM of \(15.1\% (+0.4\) ppt yoy) came in \(+0.4\) ppt above GSe. Management attributed the GPM improvement to cost saving initiatives and technology upgrade.
1H25 opex of Rmb4.15bn \((+9\%\) yoy) was inline with GSe. As a result, EBIT of Rmb3.51bn \((+5\%\) yoy) was \(- 3\%\) below GSe, with EBITM of \(6.9\% (+0.1\) ppt yoy) \(+0.1\) ppt above GSe.

Based on segment OPM disclosure, we noted that HDT OPM was flattish in 1H25 while operating loss was widened yoy, dragging down the OPM for Sinotruk's truck assembly business by 12bps yoy. On the other hand, OPM for engine business (1/3 of 1H25) expanded by 45bps yoy in 1H25, offsetting the margin contraction in truck assembly business.
Below EBIT line, higher- than- expected FX gain and other gain helped drive the NPM to \(6.7\%\) (flat yoy), \(+0.5\) ppt above GSe. NP of Rmb3.43bn \((+4\%\) yoy) was \(+5\%\) above GSe.

1H25 recorded operating cash inflow of Rmb3.66bn (- 31% yoy/- 23% qoq). Partially offset by - 61% yoy/- 34% qoq declined capex of Rmb546mn, 1H25 achieved FCF generation of Rmb3.11bn (- 31% yoy/- 7% qoq). Supported by solid FCF generation and net cash position (Rmb8.29bn as of end- 1H25), company announced interim cash dividend of Rmb1.88bn/HK\$2.04bn or HK\$0.68/share, implying \(55\%\) payout ratio - unchanged vs. last year and \(3\%\) dividend yield.
Regarding HDT industry demand, management expects 2025E industry sales

volume to be at 1mn units (implied 2H25E growth of \(+16\%\) yoy), and expects the long- term industry annual sales volume to remain at this level supported by: 1) continued growth in economic activities; 2) replacement demand brought by high industry installed base (8\~8.5mn units, with a replacement cycle of 8- 10 years, as shared by the management), and 3) increasing demand for electrification.

By region, management expects 2025E industry exports to see a slight decline yoy, with sharp decline in CIS region partially offset by solid growth in Africa and SEA, together with accelerated growth in Middle East and South America. Management highlighted the growth opportunity for China exports in Middle East and South America where used trucks from DMs still dominate the market. For Sinotruk, management reiterated full- year exports volume guidance of 150k units (implying \(18\%\) yoy growth for 2H25E). For domestic market, management highlighted Sinotruk's strategic focus on electrification and autonomous driving, expecting industry electrification rate for HDT/LDT to further rise to \(30\%\) in 2H25 (c.23% for both in 1H25).
Exhibit 1: Sinotruk results summary
Source: Company data

Sinotruk is China's largest manufacturer of heavy- duty trucks (HDTs), with \(27\%\) market share (measured by wholesale volume in 2024). It also leads in China HDT export market, with \(41\%\) of volume share in 2024. Other than the core HDT business (87%/63% of its 2024 topline/OP), Sinotruk also engages in the production of light duty trucks and supply engines mainly for specialty HDTs.

While we are constructive on the domestic truck cycle into 2025E, we believe accelerating truck electrification in China and the corresponding disruption to the HDT competitive landscape and industry margin profile is not well understood by the market. Our 2025E- 27E EPS estimates are firmly below the Visible Alpha consensus likely because we are factoring in a faster truck electrification trend as well as structural margin deterioration vs. the Street, in addition to the slowdown in export market (after

rapid growth between 2021 and 2024) driving an unfavorable shift in geographic mix (exports are much more profitable compared to domestic business). With the stock trading close to its historical mid- cycle average P/E level (11x) and close to 1SD above its 5- year average level (8.5x) despite structural margin pressure and muted earnings growth ahead, we view valuation as expensive and see better opportunities to ride the potential cyclical inflection of the domestic HDT industry elsewhere in our coverage. We therefore rate the shares at Sell.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR).
